items.title: Python3 support?
items.body: Is python3 supported, import works, get_objects returns values. summary.summarize cause program to terminate with no messages. Thanks for creating this capability.

items.title: django.template.exceptions.TemplateSyntaxError: 'staticfiles' is not a registered tag library
items.body:
Django: v3.05
Python: v3.7.4

```shell
django.template.exceptions.TemplateSyntaxError: 'staticfiles' is not a registered tag library. Must be one of:
admin_list
admin_modify
admin_urls
cache
debugger_tags
djmoney
highlighting
i18n
indent_text
l10n
log
rest_framework
static
syntax_color
truncate_letters
tz
widont
[07/Apr/2020 13:26:07] "GET /__debug__/render_panel/?store_id=a2d2b2bce44743b083f9d38f41c5bd74&panel_id=MemoryPanel HTTP/1.1" 500 275650
```
The following error is due to the fact that `{% load static from staticfiles %}` must be replaced with `{% load_static %}` over here in order to support Django 3.0

https://github.com/pympler/pympler/blob/bfc2f957831c96a39acedba25fb0da99c5a37805/pympler/templates/memory_panel.html#L1

items.title: ERROR in test_background_monitoring (tracker.test_classtracker.SnapshotTestCase) with Python 3.9.0a2
items.body:
```
======================================================================
ERROR: test_background_monitoring (tracker.test_classtracker.SnapshotTestCase)
Test background monitoring.
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/builddir/build/BUILD/Pympler-0.8/test/tracker/test_classtracker.py", line 237, in test_background_monitoring
    self.tracker.stop_periodic_snapshots()
  File "/builddir/build/BUILDROOT/python-Pympler-0.8-1.fc32.x86_64/usr/lib/python3.9/site-packages/pympler/classtracker.py", line 514, in stop_periodic_snapshots
    if self._periodic_thread and self._periodic_thread.isAlive():
AttributeError: 'PeriodicThread' object has no attribute 'isAlive'

======================================================================
ERROR: test_background_monitoring (tracker.test_classtracker.SnapshotTestCase)
Test background monitoring.
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/builddir/build/BUILD/Pympler-0.8/test/tracker/test_classtracker.py", line 151, in tearDown
    self.tracker.stop_periodic_snapshots()
  File "/builddir/build/BUILDROOT/python-Pympler-0.8-1.fc32.x86_64/usr/lib/python3.9/site-packages/pympler/classtracker.py", line 514, in stop_periodic_snapshots
    if self._periodic_thread and self._periodic_thread.isAlive():
AttributeError: 'PeriodicThread' object has no attribute 'isAlive'
```

See https://docs.python.org/3.9/whatsnew/3.9.html#removed

"The `isAlive()` method of `threading.Thread` has been removed. It was deprecated since Python 3.8. Use `is_alive()` instead."

This was found in early testing of Python 3.9 in Fedora rawhide: https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1791963 .

items.title: asizeof does not properly size Shapely geometries
items.body:
Now I don't know if "C objects" are in scope of this wonderful project but since numpy is explicitly mentioned I thought I could really use it on any other module.

I would love to use it for some memory investigations in a project using the https://github.com/Toblerity/Shapely module. *From what I know* that uses GEOS in the background which is a C library. 

```
>>> from pympler import asizeof
>>> from shapely.geometry import Point, MultiPoint
>>> point = Point(0, 0)
>>> asizeof.asizeof(point)
440
>>> many_points = [Point(0, 0) for _ in range(1000)]
>>> asizeof.asizeof(many_points)
209264
>>> multipoint = MultiPoint(many_points)  # aggregate the 1000 points in one multi-geometry
>>> asizeof.asizeof(multipoint)
440
```

The actual memory used for the `multipoint` object should be closer to the size of the `many_points` object. It definitely can't be 440 bytes.

items.title: summarize seems to cut off type string ending
items.body:
when using summarize together with muppy.get_objects() on python 3.6, the summarize result seems to cut off type strings.

for example a normal type string representation should look like this: `<class 'str'>` but when using summary.summarize i get `<class 'str` with the `'>` missing.

although this may not seem like a important issue, it is very confusing to someone expecting a complete type string. 

personally i spent 30 minutes searching through my own code until figuring out that 
1. this is done by summarize for some reason
2. none of the actuall type name is cut off (afaik)

i would try to fix this myself but i cant seem to find where this cut off happens.

items.title: dict not included in SummaryTracker.print_diff()
items.body:
`dict` variables and the values inside of them are not output when calling `print_diff()` with a `SummaryTracker`. Here's an example that demonstrates the behavior:

```
from pympler import tracker
from datetime import datetime

tr = tracker.SummaryTracker()
print('start')
tr.print_diff()

print('empty list')
list_test = []
tr.print_diff()

print('add to list')
list_test.append(datetime.now())
tr.print_diff()

print('empty dict')
dict_test = {}
tr.print_diff()

print('add to dict')
dict_test['test'] = datetime.now()
tr.print_diff()
```

Tested with 2.7.15 and 3.7.2 and neither output the any information about `dict`

items.title: Compatibility with Django debug toolbar 2(?)
items.body:
Just a heads up, Django debug toolbar is changing how panels are processed to be more like new-style middleware, presumably for an upcoming 2.0 release (and also dropping Python 2 support).

As a result, Pympler panel is broken vs current Django debug toolbar master, it hits this error "'NoneType' object has no attribute 'get'" because `debug_toolbar/middleware.py` expects process_request to return a response object.

Using:

django debug toolbar master (https://github.com/jazzband/django-debug-toolbar/commit/b650a33bb02651903540d726704a9143c73eda0a)
Pympler==0.7
Django==2.2.1

See simple example project that hits the bug on all requests: https://github.com/therefromhere/ddt_pympler_bug_example

Note that this doesn't affect the released version of Django debug toolbar yet.

items.title: How to get the size of all the objects including class instances?
items.body:
I test the following code, and the summary is incorrect. `a` use about 0.8G memory but the summary doesn't contain this information.
```
from pympler import muppy, summary, asizeof
import numpy as np


class A(object):
    def __init__(self):
        self.a = np.empty((10000, 44, 44, 9, 5), dtype=np.uint8)


_sum = summary.summarize(muppy.get_objects(include_frames=True))
summary.print_(_sum)
a = A()
print(asizeof.asizeof(a) / 1024 / 1024 / 1024)
_sum = summary.summarize(muppy.get_objects(include_frames=True))
summary.print_(_sum)

```

Output:
```
                               types |   # objects |   total size
==================================== | =========== | ============
                         <class 'str |       17530 |      3.12 MB
                        <class 'dict |        2625 |      1.49 MB
```

items.title: is there an existing way to measure memory use by stack frame?
items.body:
Hi there -

pympler is my go-to memory profiler when I am doing that sort of thing.   We have an internal long-running application that folks are having trouble identifying where large memory growth is occurring, and my usual bag of tricks e.g. with pympler, which is using a signal handler to dump out a report of current memory use, is not helping them because the objects that are taking up all the room are just dictionaries that are part of an overall caching system used by the library, e.g. there's no specific class or object we can point towards as the culprit.  

So I saw this [blog post](https://info.cloudquant.com/2018/12/numpyleaks/) that is identifying Python memory leaks by linking memory growth to actual stack frames, using some C-level tool called memleax.   They built a custom C module to identify the growth from the memleax side, then send a signal to a handler in Python to identify a callstack.      But looking at this, it seems to me that the complexity of building a C++ library to wrap around some external tool like that (also `memleax` seems to be superseded by `libleak` anyway) to track callstacks is unnecessary, because Python already has sys.settrace().   We can do what memleax does inside the Python process itself, which is, identify callstacks where memory is allocated and then wasn't released some fixed time later.

the basic idea is that instead of the usual emphasis on "find which kinds of classes / objects are using the most memory", we are instead looking for particular callstacks that are using the most memory and importantly not freeing it up after some interval that we can configure.

if a tool used sys.settrace() to intercept all frames as they occur, then stored every unit of a program's call stacks inside of a tree structure (e.g. each node in the tree stores the path to a source file and a line number, and the parent of the node is the node that called it), then used pympler to count the memory use of all the objects attached to that specific frame and its descendants (this part might be the hard part where I'm looking for input), we'd have a memory tally for every line of code.  Then if memory has grown for the past N minutes on a particular frame that has not been recovered (each node of the tree would store its last N minutes of memory growth / shrinkage), we dump out that stack to the console.    

The idea is this would let us run a program with this extra background thread turned on, and we could literally watch it show us specific source lines that are responsible for memory growth.  since after all what we really need when we are profiling memory are places in the source code that are buggy.

does this make sense and if so has this been done?   or am I inhaling too much eggnog

items.title: deprecation warning in pympler/asizeof.py
items.body:
/home/lindahl/.pyenv/versions/3.6.4/lib/python3.6/site-packages/pympler/asizeof.py:259: DeprecationWarning: unicode_internal codec has been deprecated
  u = u.encode('unicode-internal')  # see .../Lib/test/test_sys.py

https://docs.python.org/3/library/codecs.html says

Deprecated since version 3.3: This representation is obsoleted by PEP 393.

items.title: Wrong results when measuring object that uses __slots__?
items.body:
Hello there, and thanks for Pympler!

While doing a few experiments on a class that uses `__slots__` to reduce memory footprint I ran into a few unexpected results.

Testcase:

```python
import sys
print(sys.version)
from pympler import asizeof

SLOTS = ("foo", "bar")

class Foo(object):
  __slots__ = SLOTS

  def __init__(self):
    self.foo = SLOTS
    self.bar = SLOTS

print(asizeof.asized(Foo(), detail=1).format())
print("Same object? " + str(Foo().__slots__ is SLOTS))
```

Results:

```
3.6.5 (default, Jun 20 2018, 09:33:17) 
[GCC 5.4.0 20160609]
<__main__.Foo object at 0x7f143841ac88> size=304 flat=56
    foo size=176 flat=64
    __slots__ size=72 flat=72
    __class__ size=0 flat=0
    bar size=0 flat=0
Same object? True
```

Three things seem to be wrong in this case:

* the flat size of `__slots__` is 8 bytes more than the object itself
* the total size of the `Foo` instance does not account for the fact that `foo` and `__slots__` are pointing at the same object
* the flat size of `__slots__` is shown to be the same as the size

Thus, whereas I would expect in this case the total size to be 56 + 176, pympler reports it as 56 + 176 + 72.

I was able to validate similar results with Python 2.7, so it doesn't seem to be something that may be off in any specific version.

Is this a pympler bug, or am I missing some important detail on how `__slots__` are actually implemented that causes this?

items.title: Cannot import process due to empty line in /proc/self/status
items.body:
Trying to import process is failing after updating the kernel on Ubuntu 16.04


items.title: AttributeError: 'module' object has no attribute '__name__'
items.body:
In some rare cases it's possible that module object has not attribute `__name__` and the next exception is raised:
```
n [44]: summary.print_(summary.summarize(muppy.get_objects()))
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
AttributeError                            Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-44-f303f4aef1bc> in <module>()
----> 1 summary.print_(summary.summarize(muppy.get_objects()))

/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/pympler/summary.py in summarize(objects)
    118     total_size = {}
    119     for o in objects:
--> 120         otype = _repr(o)
    121         if otype in count:
    122             count[otype] += 1

/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/pympler/summary.py in _repr(o, verbosity)
    274         if len(representations[t]) < verbosity:
    275             verbosity = len(representations[t]) - 1
--> 276         res = representations[t][verbosity](o)
    277
    278     res = address.sub('', res)

/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/pympler/summary.py in <lambda>(m)
     95     ]
     96     representations[list] = _list
---> 97     module = [lambda m: "module(%s)" % m.__name__]
     98     representations[types.ModuleType] = module
     99     _set = [

AttributeError: 'module' object has no attribute '__name__'
```

Steps to reproduce:
```
In [1]: %run test_file.py  # excute any file here

In [2]: import gc

In [3]: nameless_modules = [o for o in gc.get_objects() if type(o).__name__ == 'module' and not hasattr(o, '__name__')]

In [4]: nameless_modules
Out[4]: [<module '?' (built-in)>]

In [5]: m = nameless_modules[0]

In [6]: m.__name__
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
AttributeError                            Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-6-c3d23904167a> in <module>()
----> 1 m.__name__

AttributeError: 'module' object has no attribute '__name__'
```

items.title: use system bottle
items.body: Pympler includes bottle (in `pympler/util/bottle.py`). I patched it to use system-wide bottle module and it seems to work fine (at least the tests pass). Please consider adding support for using the system version of bottle.

items.title: asizeof does not properly size numpy arrays
items.body:
Although numpy is not a part of the python standard library, it is a part of many python developer's standard toolkits. Therefore it seems like it would be useful to properly size numpy arrays. Currently asizeof does not properly size numpy arrays. eg:

```
>>> import numpy as np
>>> from pympler import asizeof
>>> example = np.arange(1000)
>>> asizeof.asizeof(example)
80
```

Clearly, an array of 1000 values should take more than 80 bytes of memory.
Fortunately numpy arrays have an "nbytes" property that indicates their size, thus

```
>>> example.nbytes
8000
```

It may be possible to get an accurate idea of numpy array memory usage using this property.

I ran these commands in Python 3.4 with pympler 0.4.3

items.title: asizeof does not properly size namedtuples
items.body:
If I run asizeof on a normal tuple, I get the following:

```
>>> from pympler import asizeof
>>> asizeof.asizeof(list(range(1000)), "foo")
41160
```

If I create a named tuple and run asizeof on that object, I don't get the correct size:

```
>>> from pympler import asizeof
>>> from collections import namedtuple
>>> TestTuple = namedtuple("TestTuple", ["a", "b"])
>>> asizeof.asizeof(TestTuple(list(range(1000)), "foo"))
120
```

I believe asizeof should be returning roughly the same values for these calls.

This output was produced on Python 3.4 using pympler 0.4.3. Perhaps this is related to #10?

items.title: asizeof seems to ignore private __attr style variables within slots

the `_dir2` routine fails to recognize slot attributes in `__attr` private variable style, which are mangled as `_<ClassName>__attr` by python

adding

```
                if a[:2]=="__" : a= '_'+c.__name__+a
```

as line 354, seems to fix issue for me.
[this isn't displayed correctly I compare the first to chars to 'underscore''underscore' and if true use the c name attribute to emulate the mangling done by python. And yeah I guess this is, because this is not the place for code, but I'm not a regular, and would just like to document a bug and a one-line fix.]

items.title: ClassTracker should detach classes when deleted
asizeof() gives incorrect values for the memory consumption of named tuples.
items.body:
From the documentation for the collections module:

"Named tuple instances do not have per-instance dictionaries, so they are lightweight and require no more memory than regular tuples."

```
Python 3.4.0 (default, Apr 11 2014, 13:05:11) 
[GCC 4.8.2] on linux
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> import pympler.asizeof
>>> import collections
>>> Point = collections.namedtuple('Point', ['x', 'y'])
>>> p = Point(11, y=22)
>>> p
Point(x=11, y=22)
>>> pympler.asizeof.asizeof(p)
1440
>>> t = 11, 22
>>> t
(11, 22)
>>> pympler.asizeof.asizeof(t)
128
```

I haven't been able to figure out the reason for the discrepancy.

items.title: pympler.asizeof does not size closures correctly.
items.body:
pympler does not look into func_closure correctly, causing it to miss memory that may be owned by a closure.  Here is a simple repro case:

  import pympler.asizeof as sz
  cp = lambda x: lambda: x
  fn = cp([1] \* 40000)
  cell = fn.func_closure[0]
  sz.asizeof(cell)   # returns 0, should return 160072 (on 32-bit machine)

This causes sz.asizeof(fn, code=True) to be something like 560 rather than 160000.

The problem is that pympler does not have special-casing for the 'cell' type, which is where python encodes data that is held by a closure.

Here is a patch that fixes this, at least in my tests.  There is an aspect of cargo-culting here, so I'm not sure the fix is totally correct, but it works on the above test case, at least.

https://gist.github.com/csilvers/9236595

items.title: No support for alternative output targets like logging
items.body:
Pympler currently seems to assume that all the memory profiling would be done in an environment where `print` statements make sense.

In my case I wanted to write a periodic memory usage dump to a log to keep track of memory utilization over longer term on a Twisted-based server application and found that pympler did not allow me to do that out of the box -- I had to copy & rewrite `pympler.summary.print_` function to return an list of formatted lines instead of printing them straight out with `print`.

As you see, it's extremely easy to fix. Take standard `traceback` module for example. It has both `print_stack` and `format_stack` methods. Same with standard library `pprint` module (`pprint` and `pformat`). With `format_` method (optionally implemented as a generator), `print_` could even be reduced to a couple of lines.

 I'm aware of `print` to logging redirection option, but it's not good in my case, because it doesn't allow to fine tune the actual output of logs, like the standard `logging` module does. And it's very important.

items.title: sys.maxunicode >= (1 << (_sizeof_Cunicode << 3)) causes assertion failure
items.body:
sys.maxunicode >= (1 << (_sizeof_Cunicode << 3)) 
causes assertion failure.

Using: 
from pympler.asizeof import asizeof 
raises the error. 

Followed these instructions:
1. Build the Pympler package:
    python setup.py build
2.a) For a system-wide installation run:
    python setup.py install
2.b) For a user-specific*\* installation run:
    python setup.py --user install
3) Test the installed Pympler package:
    python setup.py test
And, included a command window filled with the test results. 
![maxunicode](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/2746787/29406/005b6a02-4d75-11e2-82c5-c90c789c4fb2.png)
